Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Hi rooster0330, Did your dad's post-op pathology report mention anything about positive surgical margins? I was going to ask the same question. They probably saw that the prostate cancer was at the edges of the tissue that was removed, so there is high suspicion that there is a little bit of prostate cancer left. By using radiation, the hope is to completely eliminate any prostate cancer that remains in that area.
Posts.Title: radiation after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Unfortunately, it would be highly illegal for someone in the US to take a medication prescribed for someone and sell/give it to you. You may try to see if there is a clinical trial being run in India that would give him access to one of these. Abiraterone would generally be the preferred option over enzalutamide/MDV3100 for now given its longer track record and better availability. A PSA of 6.2 suggests that he may continue to get benefit from this current treatment, so who knows when the next therapy would be needed. Maybe there will be more options then. You didn't say what specific chemotherapy treatments have been used in India, but if not yet used, cabazitaxel or mitoxantrone are also potential options for refractory disease. There are also radioactive therapies that could be used for palliative effect if the bone disease becomes bothersome, and I would expect him to be receiving a bisphosphonate already.
Posts.Title: How can I get Zytiga and MDV3100 at low cost in non US countries? say India

Posts.Content: Goserelin (Zoladex) is a GnRH analog that prevents creation of testosterone by your body. Since most prostate cancers are heavily dependent upon testosterone to live and proliferate, this type of medication often has a very strong benefit in prostate cancer. Bicalutamide (Casodex) is a non-steroidal androgen receptor inhibitor. This blocks testosterone from attaching to individual cells and triggering pathways that will help them live and grow. It is also helpful to prevent a temporary worsening of symptoms when a GnRH agent is started in patients. Depending on the characteristics of one's disease, bicalutamide is often used for a limited amount of time, sometimes just for a few weeks, up to 6 months or 2 years. The duration of Goserelin (Zoladex) use is dependent on the stage and status of one's disease. The pages I linked have more information about side effects that you may find helpful.
Posts.Title: drugs

Posts.Content: That's a very modest change, and many people wouldn't consider that to necessarily be failure as above; nevertheless, the goal PSA after surgery is zero. Two main options include continued monitoring or radiation (due to it being Gleason 8, some people would use hormone therapy for 6 months around radiation). How's the recovery of continence going? The radiation doctors often prefer to allow maximum recovery of urinary continence before going with radiation.
Posts.Title: PSA creeping up after Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 I respectfully disagree that a reading of 1.8 PSA following a prostatectomy is "modest". If fact, any reading exceeding 0.2 PSA sets off flashing red lights and bells and loud whistles in my urologist's office. I was replying to the original poster with a PSA that went from 0.06 to 0.08, not about the case with PSA 1.8.

Posts.Content: Endorectal MRIs can be used to more accurately stage prostate cancer, but it usually isn't used before there's a diagnosis. I can't think of any doctor that would treat without a biopsy.
Posts.Title: Suspect Alternative to Biopsy from first time confused poster

Posts.Content: Patients with this profile may get both CT and bone scans, but there is a grayzone for what is "right" and it depends on additional information, such as your current clinical stage. They show different things; namely, the bone scan is better than CT at detecting spread of cancer to the bones (which prostate cancer likes to do), and the CT is good at the other stuff. Downside of scans includes radiation exposure, risk of interactions (such as to CT contrast), anxiety & time spent for you, risk of false positives, and cost to the healthcare system.
Posts.Title: Bone scan and CAT Scan

Posts.Content: Endorectal MRIs can be used to more accurately stage prostate cancer, but it usually isn't used before there's a diagnosis. I can't think of any doctor that would treat without a biopsy.
Posts.Title: Suspect Alternative to Biopsy from first time confused poster

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by sequoiaranger I *THOUGHT" it was exciting news, but...it seems "all" it does is block cancer uptake of testosterone. My cancer went "refractory" and was no longer tied to testosterone, so where does that leave me?? This leaves you with options. Enzalutamide (also previously known as MDV3100) blocks the activity of testosterone in a different way and works for some patients with so-called "castrate-resistant" prostate cancer, which is not the best description of what's actually happening biologically. The cancer often just comes up with another way to get testosterone, such as by making it itself. A patient with a treatment history as listed in your signature could be considered for the following therapies: -second-line hormone therapy with ketoconazole -cabazitaxel (FDA approved for patients who've failed docetaxel) -abiraterone/Zytiga -enzalutamide/Xtandi/MDV3100 -mitoxantrone A bisphosphonate or denosumab could be used in consideration of the bony metastatic disease.
Posts.Title: enzalutamide formerly MDV3100 approved USA as Xtandi

Posts.Content: Edit: Sorry, disregard this response. Missed that one of the cores was gleason 3+4, which would not be appropriate for active surveillance. ------------------------------------------------------------ In addition to potentially curative therapies like surgery and radiation, another approach that can be considered is active surveillance, where the PSA, exam, and interval biopsies will be done. This would potentially delay the need for treatments and their side effects which include possible urinary and sexual issues. The argument against it for somebody so young is that, in contrast to people in, say, their 70s-80s who are diagnosed with such minimal disease, the likelihood of the prostate cancer being the biggest health problem for a young person is higher and will most likely need treatment. It can be very helpful for patients to meet with three specialties, medical oncology, radiation oncology, and urology to hear about the potential side effects of therapies so they can make the most informed decision. As a side note, why was a PSA checked in somebody who's 40 years old? Were there symptoms or family history?
Posts.Title: biopsy result yesterday ... I have prostate cancer at 40 years old. Need advices

Posts.Content: Unless that's how you're manifesting hot flashes, shivering is unusual. Headaches and fatigue are definitely seen with Zoladex. Some people have decreased severity of symptoms as time goes by and a few have significant decreases, but every person is different. You can get more information about Goserelin (Zoladex) here, but it sounds like more discussion between you and your doctors would be helpful.

Posts.Title: biopsy result yesterday ... I have prostate cancer at 40 years old. Need advices

Posts.Content: Though it may sound like splitting hairs, the study was not designed statistically to demonstrate equivalency of the two treatments. It was designed to show noninferiority (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1212299): "The primary objectives of the trial were to determine whether intermittent androgen deprivation is noninferior to continuous androgen deprivation with respect to survival in patients with metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer and to assess quality of life with the two regimens at 3 months after randomization." "The hypothesis that the hazard ratio for death would be less than 1.20 was not rejected because the upper limit of the 90% confidence interval (equivalent to a one-sided 0.05 test) was 1.23, extending beyond the noninferiority threshold of 1.20. We therefore are unable to conclude that intermittent therapy was noninferior to continuous therapy with respect to survival. However, because the lower limit of the confidence interval (0.99) does not exclude 1.00, we cannot state that intermittent therapy was significantly inferior to continuous therapy." They were unable to show that intermittent therapy is noninferior to continuous therapy, and there indeed was a trend for improved survival in the continuous group. However, they couldn't say that intermittent therapy is not noninferior because the confidence interval crosses 1. So, statisically, the study is "not not noninferior." The lead author Dr. Hussain summed it up honestly, but sounds biased toward continuous therapy: "If a patient is coming in with newly metastatic prostate cancer, hormone treatment continuously is the standard. If they wish to do intermittent treatment, they should be counseled that based on this data, their outcome might be compromised." Sure, it "might." The data pointed in that direction, but statistically it didn't reach significance. In the end, this will probably prompt discussions about how using intermittent care is probably not as good, but there's controversy in the data, and does the patient think the quality of life difference is worth that risk?
Posts.Title: Intermittent Androgen Deprivation Not Equivalent To Continuous Treatment For Prostate

Posts.Content: It's pretty well tolerated and is promising in how well it works for folks. It has the same potential side effects as other anti-androgen medications, such as hot flashes, aches, and fatigue. Leg swelling and headache were also seen, but usually not severe. You can find more information--patient info starting at page 14--in the enzalutamide (Xtando) package insert.
Posts.Title: Enzalutamide (MDV3100)

Posts.Content: Alpharadin (radium-223) isn't an FDA approved drug, so people in the US couldn't use it outside of a clinical trial setting. Were you supposed to get it as part of a clinical trial? It appears to be under priority review by the FDA. An approved agent that works similarly but may have more issues with low blood counts is Samarium-153 (Quadramet).
Posts.Title: Bayer Alpharadin not available

Posts.Content: People with cancer have a higher risk of clots (venous thromboembolism, VTEs); the association is very well-established. A possible scenario is that the doctors performed a CT chest with contrast to evaluate broadly for causes of the shortness of breath and not only found the blood clots, but also lung masses suggestive of metastatic disease. Then, wanting to figure out the origin of the cancer, somebody on the team may have checked tumor markers for cancers most common in people with this demographic--prostate cancer, colon cancer--and found the PSA to be significantly elevated, hence the high suspicion for prostate cancer. Or, perhaps they also had CT abdomen/pelvis imaging that showed a large prostate mass. If someone doesn't want a prostate biopsy, another reasonable option would be to biopsy a metastatic mass if it's accessible by a needle--this often can diagnose both the primary cancer and confirm the existence of metastatic disease.
Posts.Title: Blood clots in each of my lungs doctor says they suspect prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bob46 What are the "4 new treatments in 4 years" to which you refer? I don't know for certain if these were the intended ones, but these have been new since 2010: Abiraterone (Zytiga) Cabazitaxel (Jevtana) Enzalutamide (Xtandi) Sipuleucel-T (Provenge)
Posts.Title: What to Do about Conflicting Advice

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by joeelio With 4 New treatments in the market in 4 years. Comtreq a year or so away. New technologies are making progress, combo therapies, 2nd generation immunology. Cometriq (XL184, cabozantinib) is FDA approved, but only for metastatic medullary thyroid cancer, so a doctor could theoretically prescribe it off-label now, but it would be next to impossible to get such a new/expensive drug approved by insurance. There have been examples of good responses in people, particularly with bone metastases, but overall enthusiasm has been moderate for it because of toxicities. 79% of patients in one trial needed to have their dose reduced because of adverse reactions.
Posts.Title: What to Do about Conflicting Advice

Posts.Content: The reason why a low PSA could be concerning is that some prostate cancers are "poorly differentiated," which means that they lose characteristics that are typical of normal prostate cells, such as producing PSA. It is uncommon, but sometimes seen, and these cancers can be more aggressive than others. Edit: In case it hasn't been emphasized enough, it's also important to consider that this may not be a cancer, and if it is a cancer, it may not be a prostate cancer.
Posts.Title: PSA .7 DRE showed Mass

Posts.Content: The reason why a low PSA could be concerning is that some prostate cancers are "poorly differentiated," which means that they lose characteristics that are typical of normal prostate cells, such as producing PSA. It is uncommon, but sometimes seen, and these cancers can be more aggressive than others. Edit: In case it hasn't been emphasized enough, it's also important to consider that this may not be a cancer, and if it is a cancer, it may not be a prostate cancer.
Posts.Title: PSA .7 DRE showed Mass

Posts.Content: The Cleveland Clinic docs are closer to standard of care. I'll quote from the NCCN guidelines for prostate cancer, v. 1.2012, MS-20: "A rise in PSA by 2 ng/mL or more above the nadir PSA (defined as the lowest PSA achieved) is the current standard definition for biochemical failure after EBRT [external beam radiation therapy] with or without neoadjuvant ADT [androgen deprivation] therapy." So first, many people would not consider a PSA of 0.9 (especially if it's just one value instead of a few increasing ones) to be biochemical recurrence. Next, the consensus "expert opinion" actually says that there's no proven survival advantage for early initiation of hormone therapy. I quote from the 2007 Update of an American Society of Clinical Oncology Practice Guideline: "In metastatic or progressive PCa, immediate versus symptom-onset institution of ADT results in a moderate decrease (17%) in relative risk (RR) for PCa-specific mortality, a moderate increase (15%) in RR for non–PCa-specific mortality, and no overall survival advantage. Therefore, the Panel cannot make a strong recommendation for early ADT initiation." So starting early hormone therapy for people with recurrent disease (typically with actual measurable disease, not just biochemical recurrence) may prevent how soon someone gets symptoms from recurrent prostate cancer, but there's no survival advantage. There are some studies that show early hormone therapy may affect how soon people develop measurable disease, but there hasn't been a definitive guideline or new data to change this thought about survival since that time. There are providers who start hormone therapy if the PSA doubling time is becoming shorter even when a patient lacks symptoms, but there's controversy about this too. Ultimately, the choice would be up to you since you've already found doctors on both sides of the fence, but hormone therapy has real potential side effects, especially for someone who may live quite a long time before ever encountering complications from prostate cancer.
Posts.Title: What to Do about Conflicting Advice

Posts.Content: Only you can decide what the acceptable risks and side effects are. A benefit for some people is that getting the prostatectomy leaves the option of salvage radiation treatment. Why not meet with both urology and radiation oncology and decide what's best for you?
Posts.Title: Radiation vs robotic prostatectomy, what should I do?

Posts.Content: Only you can decide what the acceptable risks and side effects are. A benefit for some people is that getting the prostatectomy leaves the option of salvage radiation treatment. Why not meet with both urology and radiation oncology and decide what's best for you?
Posts.Title: Radiation vs robotic prostatectomy, what should I do?

Posts.Content: The medical oncologist should be the quarterback of your team and can almost always give the hormone shots. That's the only doctor that somebody in your situation would probably see regularly. Radiation oncologists usually are intermittently involved in care as needed, such as to radiate the prostate or deal with painful bony lesions. I wouldn't necessarily jump to the conclusion that the urologist is being money-hungry. Doctors default to continuing to be available for patients--for example, they can't abandon patients--and if there aren't any active urologic issues like urinary obstruction that the urologist is managing, I think it's unlikely the urologist would protest someone wanting to get hormone shots with their medical oncologist.
Posts.Title: 2 or 3 Doctors ?

Posts.Content: The enzalutamide (Xtandi/MDV3100) package insert does not explicitly describe the incidence of sexual side effects, although you can see from the full list of adverse effects on pages 3 & 4 that it's a well-tolerated medication with a low rate of severe side effects. The patients who participated in the AFFIRM trial (New England Journal of Medicine link--subscription required to read full article) were required to have very low levels of testosterone, which in the US generally means that they are also receiving a medication such as leuprolide (Lupron)--in some other places, these men have had their testicles removed (orchiectomy). With those low levels of testosterone, men essentially have no sexual drive. The study also did not list rates of sexual side effects, presumably since in this population, it would already be very high due to their other anti-hormonal therapy.
Posts.Title: MDV3100 side effects

Posts.Content: You can find some information about patient assistance options here. If he can't get coverage/assistance for abiraterone (zytiga), there are many other reasonable choices for treatment. The most affordable ones would include ketoconazole or docetaxel.
Posts.Title: Zytiga question
